Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Summer Research Projects in Contemporary Physics for Women and Minorities
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the renewal of the Research Experiences for Undergraduates site in Physics at the University of Chicago. The award supports eight undergraduate students for ten weeks of summer research in topics including high-energy physics, cosmic-ray and astrophysics, general relativity, condensed-matter physics, nonlinear dynamics, and biophysics. The students will conduct leading-edge physics research while developing strong peer relationships with their cohort of diverse physics students. Regular work on the research project is augmented with formal presentations from faculty members on their research, and with field trips to both Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory and Argonne National Laboratory. The interns will learn to communicate science by submitting a written report and making an oral presentation on their work. The program provides students with exposure to the breadth and unity of physics and brings the REU students into contact with one another. This creates the peer interactions among students that increase the program's excitement and vitality.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Department of Physics at the University of Chicago ran a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site targeting underrepresented minority and women students for participation in research, in order to encourage these students to pursue a career in the physical sciences. The core of the program for each student was a well-defined ten-week long summer research project under the supervision of a University of Chicago faculty member.  Projects were distributed among high-energy phyiscs, astrophysics & cosmology, general relativity, condensed matter physics, AMO, mathematical physics, and biophysics.  Faculty gave talks to the students about their research twice-a-week, ensuring that students were exposed to the pertinent issues of the field at a level appropriate to their backgrounds and interest.  In addition, there were tours of nearby Argonne National Laboratory and Fermilab.  Students were housed together in a nearby dormitory & a variety of social activities were organized to build community and encourage the development of a strong cohort of future scientists.  Students were also asked to give a 10-minute presentation (in a style similar to an APS conference) and write a short paper on their summer research, which provided students with the opportunity to practice communicating science.   Of the 25 students (some returnees) supported by the award, 15 are underrepresented minorities (4 African-American, 11 Hispanic) and 9 are non-minority women.
